content: +++http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2009/05/07/dems_shun_specter_undercut_obama_and_reid_96381.html Soon even that allegiance came into question. This week Specter told the New York Times that Republican Norm Coleman should be seated over his Democratic opponent Al Franken, in Minnesota's still disputed Senate race. "Arlen," Reid asked Specter on the Senate floor. "What's going on here?" "I forgot what team I was on," Specter replied. Specter tried to retract the statement. But the damage was done. No Democrats were excited to step aside and offer Specter a key place in the Senate committee pecking order. Specter gave opponents reason to reject him. Tuesday night, the Senate voted to strip Specter of his seniority. Specter has served in the Senate for twenty-nine years. The vote left him with the power of a freshman. Specter responded Wednesday morning with a written statement, again noting Reid's promise that "I would have the same seniority as if I had been elected as a Democrat in 1980." Reid remains optimistic. He told CNN that, "we can try to work something out with individual chairmen." hahahahhahahahaha... This could make me happy for days.

"Arlen," Reid asked Specter on the Senate floor. "What's going on here?" "I forgot what team I was on," Specter replied. Specter tried to retract the statement. But the damage was done. No Democrats were excited to step aside and offer Specter a key place in the Senate committee pecking order. Specter gave opponents reason to reject him. Tuesday night, the Senate voted to strip Specter of his seniority. Specter has served in the Senate for twenty-nine years. The vote left him with the power of a freshman. Specter responded Wednesday morning with a written statement, again noting Reid's promise that "I would have the same seniority as if I had been elected as a Democrat in 1980." Reid remains optimistic. He told CNN that, "we can try to work something out with individual chairmen." hahahahhahahahaha... This could make me happy for days.

Switching parties midstream is just a selfish act. He knows he can't win as a Republican so he jumped ship. He has lost any credibility he evert had, and I actually liked him as a moderate Republican. Plus he is 79 years old now and is running for another term when he will already be 80. He is the poster child for term limits.

content: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: -snip-Switching parties midstream is just a selfish act. He knows he can't win as a Republican so he jumped ship. He has lost any credibility he evert had, and I actually liked him as a moderate Republican. Plus he is 79 years old now and is running for another term when he will already be 80. He is the poster child for term limits. First a LOt of the people int he Repub party that voted for Mr. Specter have left the party, his support int he general election has always been based on Moderate Repubs, independents and Moderate Demos and if he ran against Mr. Toomey in the general election I would give odds on him winning, which may be why many Pa Repubs are pushing Mr. Ridge as an alternative. Second the law in Pa is setup so that he had to change parties before the primaries to be allowed to run except on the Repub party ticket. The voting laws in Pa are setup to favor the two major parties by making it very hard and expensive to get on ballots if not a Repub or Demo and by mak it hard to switch parties near an election. This message has been edited. Last edited by: rayld2, Fri 08 May 2009 11:16 AM
